title: 104_hr1191
content: The Act titled "Victims of Abuse Access to Health Insurance Act" prohibits health insurance discrimination against victims of certain crimes. The "Victims of Abuse Access to Health Insurance Act" prohibits health insurers from discriminating against individuals who are victims of domestic violence. Insurers cannot deny, cancel, or limit coverage based on domestic violence status, and conditions resulting from domestic violence cannot be considered pre-existing. The term "preexisting condition" refers to a diagnosed or treated condition prior to the start of health coverage, without considering any waiting period. SEC. 3. CIVIL AND CRIMINAL REMEDIES AND PENALTIES. Whoever violates this Act may face fines, civil penalties, and civil actions. Individuals affected by the prohibited conduct can seek relief through civil actions, including injunctive relief and damages. The plaintiff may recover statutory damages of $5,000 per violation instead of actual damages. Both Federal and State courts have concurrent jurisdiction over actions under this section. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "domestic violence" under this Act includes acts like causing bodily injury, assault, sexual assault, or engaging in conduct that instills fear of bodily harm in a domestic or family relationship. The term "insurer" in the Act refers to entities such as health benefit plans, health care providers, self-insuring entities, and Federal or State agencies involved in public health protection. The curr_chunk discusses various types of health insurance arrangements, including welfare arrangements, health insurance plans, workers' compensation insurance related to medical benefits, and automobile medical insurance. Automobile medical insurance is included in the discussion of different health insurance arrangements, specifically related to medical benefits. The Act specifically relates to insurance business, regulations will be issued by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and the Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
